awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A mathematics communication and collaboration system
awd_abstract_narration:
This project researches and develops a novel mathematics communication and collaboration system. Mathematics is the foundation of Science and Technology, and national competence in the STEM fields is essential to maintaining our competitive edge on a global scale. Math literacy hinges on effective communication of mathematical concepts and processes. However, despite significant advances in pedagogical methods, the way we communicate mathematics remains curiously behind the times. Preliminary customer and market research has revealed that the lack of adequate communication tools for mathematical and technical expressions is holding back the advance of mathematics in online environments such as online tutoring. Moreover, the scarcity of effective communication tools has reinforced the long-standing preconception that math is primarily a solitary activity, and it has created an unintended and harmful selection bias restricting the diversity of students entering STEM fields. This project fills the void of adequate math communications tools with an dynamic, interactive system for communicating mathematical derivations in real-time in an online environment. The system facilitates student-student and student-teacher remote communication of mathematics, and it is particularly suited for student-tutor communication on online tutoring platforms.

The math communication and collaboration system this project develops leverages the company's proprietary equation manipulation technology. This system employs an integrated math engine and a touch-based interface allowing users to manipulate equations using simple drag-and-drop gestures. It is built on a game-engine allowing for multi-player support. This project integrates the equation manipulation technology into a networked multi-user interface to connect one or more users for real-time communication of mathematical derivations. The project researches the precise needs of students, teachers, and online tutors to tailor the user interface to the specific needs of online mathematics communication. Specific problems the project researches include multi-player networking and matchmaking functionality, optimal network architecture for the system, transfer of control between users for effective communication, integration of traditional communication tools within the system, and reduction of latency time to enhance real-time interactivity. Successful completion of the project will result in a first-of-its-kind math communication system that allows users in different places to connect online and communicate a mathematical derivation as it is happening, and as easily as if they were in the same room. The primary project deliverable is a minimum viable product to be piloted and vetted through the company?s existing math app.

por.por_cntn:
This SBIR Phase I project researched the technical feasibility and commercial viability of MathTalk, a novel mathematics communication and collaboration system. The project developed a fully-functioning prototype for MathTalk for use within the the company’s transformative mathematics platform, Figure. The demo version interfaces with Figure to create an online environment where two or more users can connect to solve equations collaboratively and communicate the process in realtime. MathTalk leverages Figure’s intuitive drag-and-drop interface for manipulating equations to create a tool that solves the outstanding problem of communicating mathematics in a digital environment where the participants are not in the same physical location. As such it is designed to address the critical needs of students, teachers, and online tutors who require a better way to communicate math. 

 

The primary objective of the Phase I Project was to develop Figure into a collaboration and communication platform. This was accomplished by adding a peer-to-peer networking layer to the platform and employing the tools and practices of multiplayer gaming to create an interactive and responsive shared work environment. The underlying architecture for MathTalk is now patent-pending. The demo-version concretizes the core features of MathTalk by allowing two or more users to login to a personal and secure user account, invite trusted contacts to connect, and join private rooms for collaborative sessions. Once a shared session has been established, all connected users can input equations, manipulate them, and communicate the process as it is happening. The system is truly collaborative, allowing users to swap control over the shared mathematical expressions. As such, for remote communication of mathematics, it restores the rapid back-and-forth interaction that face-to-face math communication relies on.

 

In addition to completing the MathTalk demo, the Phase I project restructured the architecture of Figure, expanded its capabilities, and made general improvements to its overall usability. To improve the scalability of Figure and pave the road for the MathTalk integration the math engine and input system were overhauled. The math capabilities were expanded with the goal of moving beyond the Algebra I level to Geometry and Trigonometry and Algebra II. In addition, the project made general improvements to the user interface of Figure that greatly improved the usability and lowered the barrier to entry. This included incorporating a set of tutorial videos explaining the general features of Figure, and refining and building two interactive tutorials to gently guide first-time users through the basics of inputing and manipulating equations. 

 

Figure is available for download, and incorporating MathTalk into the live version of Figure is a critical task of this project’s Phase II proposal. More information including download links and demo videos are available on the website (www.figuremath.com), or upon request by contacting the company (info@figuremath.com).
